introduction.p: Based on the magnetic force law, Eq. we can give the following operational definition of the magnetic field.

p.em: Magnetic field B at a point in space is equal to one unit of magnetic field if force on a particle of charge 1\text{ C} moving at speed 1\text{ m/s} perpendicularly to the field experiences a force of magnitude 1\text{ N}. This unit of magnetic field is called Tesla, which is denoted by letter \text{T}.

introduction.p: We can write Tesla in terms of fundamental units as \text{kg/A.s}. You can express Tesla in various other ways, such as \text{V.s/m}^2.

It turns out that 1 Tesla is too large a unit for geophysical measurements, and another unit called Gauss (\text{G}) is in common use, where 10,000 Gauss = 1 Tesla.
1\ \textrm{T} = 10^4\ \textrm{G}.
Earth's magnetic field is approximately 0.5\text{ Gauss} while magnetic field of a refrigerator magnet is around 1\text{ Tesla}. Magnetic field used in an Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) machine is around 2\text{ Tesla}. Some typical values of magnetic fields in nature and lab are given in so that you can get a feel for the order of magnitude in various situations. As you can see magnetic field in nature varies over 18 orders of magnitude, from less than 10^{-10}\text{ T} in the interstellar space to more than 10^8\text{ T} in neutron stars.
